\title{ IV. Classical Statistical Mechanics }

\section{IV.A General Definitions}

  • Statistical Mechanics is a probabilistic approach to equilibrium macroscopic properties of large numbers of degrees of freedom.

\begin{abstract} As discussed in chapter I, equilibrium properties of macroscopic bodies are phenomenologically described by the laws of thermodynamics. The macro-state MMM, depends on a relatively small number of thermodynamic coordinates. To provide a more fundamental derivation of these properties, we can examine the dynamics of the many degrees of freedom NNN, comprising a macroscopic body. Description of each micro-state μ\muμ, requires an enormous amount of information, and the corresponding time evolution, governed by the Hamiltonian equations (discussed in chapter II), is usually quite complicated. Rather than following the evolution of an individual (pure) micro-state, statistical mechanics examines an ensemble of micro-states corresponding to a given (mixed) macro-state. It aims to provide the probabilities pM(μ)p_{M}(\mu)pM​(μ), for the equilibrium ensemble. Liouville's theorem justifies the assumption that all accessible micro-states are equally likely in an equilibrium ensemble. As discussed in chapter III, such assignment of probabilities is subjective. In this chapter we shall provide unbiased estimates of pM(μ)p_{M}(\mu)pM​(μ) for a number of different equilibrium ensembles. A central conclusion is that in the thermodynamic limit of large NNN all these ensembles are in fact equivalent. In contrast to kinetic theory, equilibrium statistical mechanics leaves out the question of how various systems achieve equilibrium. \end{abstract}

\section{IV.B The Microcanonical Ensemble}

Our starting point in thermodynamics is a mechanically and adiabatically isolated system. In the absence of heat or work input to the system, the internal energy EEE, and the generalized coordinates x\mathbf{x}x, are fixed, specifying a macro-state M≡(E,x).M \equiv(E, \mathbf{x}) .M≡(E,x). The corresponding set of mixed micro-states form the microcanonical ensemble. In classical statistical mechanics, these microstates are defined by points in phase space, their time evolution governed by a Hamiltonian H(μ)\mathcal{H}(\mu)H(μ), as discussed in Chapter II. Since the Hamiltonian equations (II.1) conserve the total energy of a given system, all micro-states are confined to the surface H(μ)=E\mathcal{H}(\mu)=EH(μ)=E in phase space. Assume that there are no other conserved quantities, so that all points on this surface are mutually accessible. The central postulate of statistical mechanics is that the equilibrium probability distribution is given by

p(E,x)(μ)=1Ω(E,x)⋅{1 for H(μ)=E0 otherwise p_{(E, \mathbf{x})}(\mu)=\frac{1}{\Omega(E, \mathbf{x})} \cdot \begin{cases}1 & \text { for } \mathcal{H}(\mu)=E \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}p(E,x)​(μ)=Ω(E,x)1​⋅{10​ for H(μ)=E otherwise ​

Some remarks and clarification on the above postulate are in order:

(1) Boltzmann's assumption of equal a priori equilibrium probabilities refers to the above postulate, which is in fact the unbiased probability estimate in phase space subject to the constraint of constant energy. This assignment is consistent with, but not required by, Liouville's theorem. Note that the phase space, specifying the microstates μ\muμ, must be composed of canonically conjugate pairs. Under a canonical change of variables, μ→μ′\mu \rightarrow \mu^{\prime}μ→μ′, volumes in phase space are left invariant. The Jacobian of such transformations is unity, and the transformed probability, p(μ′)=p(μ)∣∂μ/∂μ′∣p\left(\mu^{\prime}\right)=p(\mu)\left|\partial \mu / \partial \mu^{\prime}\right|p(μ′)=p(μ)∣∂μ/∂μ′∣, is again uniform on the surface of constant energy.

(2) The normalization factor Ω(E,x)\Omega(E, \mathbf{x})Ω(E,x), is the area of the surface of constant energy EEE in phase space. To avoid subtleties associated with densities that are non-zero only a surface, is sometimes more convenient to define the microcanonical ensemble by requiring E−Δ≤H(μ)≤E+ΔE-\Delta \leq \mathcal{H}(\mu) \leq E+\DeltaE−Δ≤H(μ)≤E+Δ, i.e. assigning the energy of the ensemble up to an uncertainty of Δ.\Delta .Δ. In this case, the accessible phase space forms a shell of thickness Δ\DeltaΔ around the surface of energy E.E .E. The normalization is now the volume of the shell, Ω′≈2ΔΩ.\Omega^{\prime} \approx 2 \Delta \Omega .Ω′≈2ΔΩ. Since Ω\OmegaΩ typically depends exponentially on EEE, as long as Δ∼O(E0)\Delta \sim \mathcal{O}\left(E^{0}\right)Δ∼O(E0) (or even O(E1))\left.\mathcal{O}\left(E^{1}\right)\right)O(E1)), the difference between the surface and volume of the shell is negligible in the E∝N→∞E \propto N \rightarrow \inftyE∝N→∞ limit, and we shall use Ω\OmegaΩ and Ω′\Omega^{\prime}Ω′ interchangeably.

(3) The entropy of this uniform probability distribution is given by

S(E,x)=kBln⁡Ω(E,x)S(E, \mathbf{x})=k_{B} \ln \Omega(E, \mathbf{x})S(E,x)=kB​lnΩ(E,x)

An additional factor of kBk_{B}kB​ is introduced compared to the definition of eq.(III.68), so that the entropy has the correct dimensions of energy per degrees Kelvin, used in thermodynamics. Ω\OmegaΩ and SSS are not changed by a canonical change of coordinates in phase space. For a collection of independent systems, the overall allowed phase space is the product of individual ones, i.e. ΩTotal =∏iΩi.\Omega_{\text {Total }}=\prod_{i} \Omega_{i} .ΩTotal ​=∏i​Ωi​. The resulting entropy is thus additive, as expected for an extensive quantity.

Various results in thermodynamics now follow from eq.(IV.1), provided that we consider macroscopic systems with many degrees of freedom. - The Zeroth law: Equilibrium properties are discussed in thermodynamics by placing two previously isolated systems in contact, and allowing them to exchange heat. We can similarly bring together two microcanonical systems, and allowing them to exchange energy, but not work. If the original systems have energies E1E_{1}E1​ and E2E_{2}E2​ respectively, the combined system has energy E=E1+E2.E=E_{1}+E_{2} .E=E1​+E2​. Assuming that interactions between the two parts are small, each micro-state of the joint system corresponds to a pair of micro-states of the two components, i.e. μ=μ1⊗μ2\mu=\mu_{1} \otimes \mu_{2}μ=μ1​⊗μ2​, and H(μ1⊗μ2)=H1(μ1)+H2(μ2).\mathcal{H}\left(\mu_{1} \otimes \mu_{2}\right)=\mathcal{H}_{1}\left(\mu_{1}\right)+\mathcal{H}_{2}\left(\mu_{2}\right) .H(μ1​⊗μ2​)=H1​(μ1​)+H2​(μ2​). As the joint system is in a microcanonical ensemble of energy E=E1+E2E=E_{1}+E_{2}E=E1​+E2​, in equilibrium

pE(μ1⊗μ2)=1Ω(E)⋅{1 for H1(μ1)+H2(μ2)=E0 otherwise p_{E}\left(\mu_{1} \otimes \mu_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{\Omega(E)} \cdot \begin{cases}1 & \text { for } \mathcal{H}_{1}\left(\mu_{1}\right)+\mathcal{H}_{2}\left(\mu_{2}\right)=E \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}pE​(μ1​⊗μ2​)=Ω(E)1​⋅{10​ for H1​(μ1​)+H2​(μ2​)=E otherwise ​

Since only the overall energy is fixed, the total allowed phase space is computed from

Ω(E)=∫dE1Ω1(E1)Ω2(E−E1)=∫dE1exp⁡[S1(E1)+S2(E−E1)kB]\Omega(E)=\int d E_{1} \Omega_{1}\left(E_{1}\right) \Omega_{2}\left(E-E_{1}\right)=\int d E_{1} \exp \left[\frac{S_{1}\left(E_{1}\right)+S_{2}\left(E-E_{1}\right)}{k_{B}}\right]Ω(E)=∫dE1​Ω1​(E1​)Ω2​(E−E1​)=∫dE1​exp[kB​S1​(E1​)+S2​(E−E1​)​]

The properties of the two systems in the new joint equilibrium state are implicit in eq.(IV.3). We can make them explicit by examining the entropy that follows from eq.(IV.4). Extensivity of entropies suggests that S1S_{1}S1​ and S2S_{2}S2​, are proportional to the number of particles in the systems, making the integrand in eq.(IV.4) an exponentially large quantity. Hence the integral can be equated by the saddle point method to the maximum value of the integrand, obtained for energies E1∗E_{1}^{*}E1∗​ and E2∗=E−E1∗E_{2}^{*}=E-E_{1}^{*}E2∗​=E−E1∗​, i.e.

S(E)=kBln⁡Ω(E)≈S1(E1∗)+S2(E2∗)S(E)=k_{B} \ln \Omega(E) \approx S_{1}\left(E_{1}^{*}\right)+S_{2}\left(E_{2}^{*}\right)S(E)=kB​lnΩ(E)≈S1​(E1∗​)+S2​(E2∗​)

The position of the maximum is obtained by extremizing the exponent in eq.(IV.4) with respect to E1E_{1}E1​, resulting in the condition,

∂S1∂E1∣x1=∂S2∂E2∣x2\left.\frac{\partial S_{1}}{\partial E_{1}}\right|_{\mathbf{x}_{\mathbf{1}}}=\left.\frac{\partial S_{2}}{\partial E_{2}}\right|_{\mathbf{x}_{\mathbf{2}}}∂E1​∂S1​​∣∣∣∣∣​x1​​=∂E2​∂S2​​∣∣∣∣∣​x2​​

Although all joint micro-states are equally likely, the above results indicate that there are an exponentially larger number of states in the vicinity of (E1∗,E2∗)\left(E_{1}^{*}, E_{2}^{*}\right)(E1∗​,E2∗​). Originally, the joint system starts in the vicinity of the point (E1,E2)\left(E_{1}, E_{2}\right)(E1​,E2​). After the exchange of energy takes place, the combined system explores a whole set of new micro-states. The probabilistic arguments provide no information on the dynamics of evolution amongst these microstates, or on the amount of time needed to establish equilibrium. However, once sufficient time has elapsed so that the assumption of equal a priori probabilities is again valid, the system is overwhelmingly likely to be at a state with internal energies (E1∗,E2∗)\left(E_{1}^{*}, E_{2}^{*}\right)(E1∗​,E2∗​). At this equilibrium point, condition (IV.6) is satisfied, specifying a relation between two functions of state. These state functions are thus equivalent to empirical temperatures, and indeed, consistent with the fundamental result of thermodynamics, we have

∂S∂E∣x=1T\left.\frac{\partial S}{\partial E}\right|_{\mathbf{x}}=\frac{1}{T}∂E∂S​∣∣∣∣∣​x​=T1​
  • The first law: We next inquire about the variations of S(E,x)S(E, \mathbf{x})S(E,x) with x\mathbf{x}x, by changing the coordinates by δx\delta \mathbf{x}δx. This results in doing work on the system by an amount dW=J⋅δxd W=\mathbf{J} \cdot \delta \mathbf{x}dW=J⋅δx, and changes the internal energy to E+J⋅δx.E+\mathbf{J} \cdot \delta \mathbf{x} .E+J⋅δx. The first order change in entropy is given by
δS=S(E+J⋅δx,x+δx)−S(E,x)=(∂S∂E∣xJ+∂S∂x∣E)⋅δx\delta S=S(E+\mathbf{J} \cdot \delta \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}+\delta \mathbf{x})-S(E, \mathbf{x})=\left(\left.\frac{\partial S}{\partial E}\right|_{\mathbf{x}} \mathbf{J}+\left.\frac{\partial S}{\partial \mathbf{x}}\right|_{E}\right) \cdot \delta \mathbf{x}δS=S(E+J⋅δx,x+δx)−S(E,x)=(∂E∂S​∣∣∣∣∣​x​J+∂x∂S​∣∣∣∣∣​E​)⋅δx

This change will occur spontaneously, taking the system into a more probable state, unless the quantity in brackets in zero. Using eq.(IV.7), this allows us to identify the derivatives

∂S∂xi∣E,xj≠i=−JiT\left.\frac{\partial S}{\partial x_{i}}\right|_{E, x_{j \neq i}}=-\frac{J_{i}}{T}∂xi​∂S​∣∣∣∣∣​E,xj=i​​=−TJi​​

Having thus identified all variations of SSS, we have

dS(E,x)=dET−J⋅dxT,⟹dE=TdS+J⋅dxd S(E, \mathbf{x})=\frac{d E}{T}-\frac{\mathbf{J} \cdot d \mathbf{x}}{T}, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad d E=T d S+\mathbf{J} \cdot d \mathbf{x}dS(E,x)=TdE​−TJ⋅dx​,⟹dE=TdS+J⋅dx

allowing us to identify the heat input dQ=TdSd Q=T d SdQ=TdS.

  • The second law: Clearly, the above statistical definition of equilibrium rests on the presence of many degrees of freedom N≫1N \gg 1N≫1, which make it exponentially unlikely in NNN, that the combined systems is found with component energies different from (E1∗,E2∗).\left(E_{1}^{*}, E_{2}^{*}\right) .(E1∗​,E2∗​). By this construction, the equilibrium point has a larger number of accessible states than the starting point, i.e.
Ω1(E1∗,x1)Ω2(E2∗,x2)≥Ω1(E1,x1)Ω2(E2,x2)\Omega_{1}\left(E_{1}^{*}, \mathbf{x}_{1}\right) \Omega_{2}\left(E_{2}^{*}, \mathbf{x}_{2}\right) \geq \Omega_{1}\left(E_{1}, \mathbf{x}_{1}\right) \Omega_{2}\left(E_{2}, \mathbf{x}_{2}\right)Ω1​(E1∗​,x1​)Ω2​(E2∗​,x2​)≥Ω1​(E1​,x1​)Ω2​(E2​,x2​)

In the process of evolving to the more likely (and more densely populated) regions, there is an irreversible loss of information, accompanied by an increase in entropy,

δS=S1(E1∗)+S2(E2∗)−S1(E1)−S2(E2)≥0\delta S=S_{1}\left(E_{1}^{*}\right)+S_{2}\left(E_{2}^{*}\right)-S_{1}\left(E_{1}\right)-S_{2}\left(E_{2}\right) \geq 0δS=S1​(E1∗​)+S2​(E2∗​)−S1​(E1​)−S2​(E2​)≥0

as required by the second law of thermodynamics. When the two bodies are first brought into contact, the equality in eq.(IV.6) does not hold. The change in entropy is such that

δS=(∂S1∂E1∣x1−∂S2∂E2∣x2)δE1=(1T1−1T2)δE1≥0\delta S=\left(\left.\frac{\partial S_{1}}{\partial E_{1}}\right|_{\mathbf{x}_{1}}-\left.\frac{\partial S_{2}}{\partial E_{2}}\right|_{\mathbf{x}_{2}}\right) \delta E_{1}=\left(\frac{1}{T_{1}}-\frac{1}{T_{2}}\right) \delta E_{1} \geq 0δS=(∂E1​∂S1​​∣∣∣∣∣​x1​​−∂E2​∂S2​​∣∣∣∣∣​x2​​)δE1​=(T1​1​−T2​1​)δE1​≥0

i.e. heat (energy) flows from the hotter to the colder body, as in Clausius's statement of the second law.

  • Stability conditions: Since the point (E1∗,E2∗)\left(E_{1}^{*}, E_{2}^{*}\right)(E1∗​,E2∗​) is a maximum, the second derivative of S1(E1)+S2(E2)S_{1}\left(E_{1}\right)+S_{2}\left(E_{2}\right)S1​(E1​)+S2​(E2​) must be negative at this point, i.e.
∂2S1∂E12∣x1+∂2S2∂E22∣x2≤0\left.\frac{\partial^{2} S_{1}}{\partial E_{1}^{2}}\right|_{\mathbf{x}_{1}}+\left.\frac{\partial^{2} S_{2}}{\partial E_{2}^{2}}\right|_{\mathbf{x}_{2}} \leq 0∂E12​∂2S1​​∣∣∣∣∣​x1​​+∂E22​∂2S2​​∣∣∣∣∣​x2​​≤0

Applying the above condition to two parts of the same system, the condition of thermal stability, Cx≥0C_{\mathbf{x}} \geq 0Cx​≥0, as discussed in section (I.I), is regained. Similarly, the second order changes in eq.(IV.8) must be negative, requiring that the matrtix ∂2S/∂xi∂xj∣E\partial^{2} S /\left.\partial x_{i} \partial x_{j}\right|_{E}∂2S/∂xi​∂xj​∣E​ be positive definite.

\section{IV.C Two-Level Systems}

Consider NNN impurity atoms trapped in a solid matrix. Each impurity can be in one of two states, with energies 0 and ϵ\epsilonϵ respectively. This example is somewhat different from the situations considered so far, in that the allowed micro-states are discrete. Liouville's theorem applies to Hamiltonian evolution in a continuous phase space. Although, there is less ambiguity in enumeration of discrete states, the dynamics that ensures that all allowed micro-states are equally accessed will remain unspecified for the moment. (An example from quantum mechanical evolution will be presented later on.)

The micro-states of the two level system are specified by the set of occupation numbers {ni}\left\{n_{i}\right\}{ni​}, where ni=0n_{i}=0ni​=0 or 1 depending on whether the ith i^{\text {th }}ith  impurity is in its ground state or excited. The overall energy is

H({ni})=ϵ∑i=1Nni≡ϵN1\mathcal{H}\left(\left\{n_{i}\right\}\right)=\epsilon \sum_{i=1}^{N} n_{i} \equiv \epsilon N_{1}H({ni​})=ϵi=1∑N​ni​≡ϵN1​

where N1N_{1}N1​ is the total number of excited impurities. The macro-state is specified by the total energy EEE, and the number of impurities N.N .N. The microcanonical probability is thus

p({ni})=1Ω(E,N)δϵ∑ini,Ep\left(\left\{n_{i}\right\}\right)=\frac{1}{\Omega(E, N)} \delta_{\epsilon \sum_{i} n_{i}, E}p({ni​})=Ω(E,N)1​δϵ∑i​ni​,E​

As there are N1=E/ϵN_{1}=E / \epsilonN1​=E/ϵ excited impurities, the normalization Ω\OmegaΩ is the number of ways of choosing N1N_{1}N1​ excited levels among the available NNN, and given by the binomial coefficient

Ω(E,N)=N!N1!(N−N1)!\Omega(E, N)=\frac{N !}{N_{1} !\left(N-N_{1}\right) !}Ω(E,N)=N1​!(N−N1​)!N!​

The entropy

S(E,N)=kBln⁡N!N1!(N−N1)!S(E, N)=k_{B} \ln \frac{N !}{N_{1} !\left(N-N_{1}\right) !}S(E,N)=kB​lnN1​!(N−N1​)!N!​

can be simplified by Stirling's formula in the limit of N1,N≫1N_{1}, N \gg 1N1​,N≫1 to

S(E,N)≈−NkB[N1Nln⁡N1N+N−N1Nln⁡N−N1N]=−NkB[(ENϵ)ln⁡(ENϵ)+(1−ENϵ)ln⁡(1−ENϵ)]\begin{aligned} S(E, N) & \approx-N k_{B}\left[\frac{N_{1}}{N} \ln \frac{N_{1}}{N}+\frac{N-N_{1}}{N} \ln \frac{N-N_{1}}{N}\right] \\ &=-N k_{B}\left[\left(\frac{E}{N \epsilon}\right) \ln \left(\frac{E}{N \epsilon}\right)+\left(1-\frac{E}{N \epsilon}\right) \ln \left(1-\frac{E}{N \epsilon}\right)\right] \end{aligned}S(E,N)​≈−NkB​[NN1​​lnNN1​​+NN−N1​​lnNN−N1​​]=−NkB​[(NϵE​)ln(NϵE​)+(1−NϵE​)ln(1−NϵE​)]​

The equilibrium temperature can now be calculated from eq.(IV.7) as

1T=∂S∂E∣N=−kBϵln⁡(ENϵ−E)\frac{1}{T}=\left.\frac{\partial S}{\partial E}\right|_{N}=-\frac{k_{B}}{\epsilon} \ln \left(\frac{E}{N \epsilon-E}\right)T1​=∂E∂S​∣∣∣∣∣​N​=−ϵkB​​ln(Nϵ−EE​)

Alternatively, the internal energy at a temperature TTT, is given by

E(T)=Nϵexp⁡(ϵkBT)+1E(T)=\frac{N \epsilon}{\exp \left(\frac{\epsilon}{k_{B} T}\right)+1}E(T)=exp(kB​Tϵ​)+1Nϵ​

The internal energy is a monotonic function of temperature, increasing from a minimum value of 0 at T=0T=0T=0 to a maximum value of Nϵ/2N \epsilon / 2Nϵ/2 at infinite temperature. It is, however, possible to start with energies larger than Nϵ/2N \epsilon / 2Nϵ/2, which correspond to negative temperatures from eq.(IV.20). The origin of the negative temperature is the decrease in the number of microstates with increasing energy, the opposite of what happens in most systems. Two level systems have an upper bound on their energy, and very few microstates close to this maximal energy. Hence increased energy leads to more order in the system. However, once a negative temperature system is brought into contact with the rest of the universe (or any portion of it without an upper bound in energy), it loses its excess energy and comes to equilibrium at a positive temperature. The world of negative temperatures is quite unusual in that systems can be cooled by adding heat, and heated by removing it. There are physical examples of systems temporarily prepared at a metastable equilibrium of negative temperature in lasers, and for magnetic spins. The heat capacity of the system, given by

C=dEdT=NkB(ϵkBT)2exp⁡(ϵkBT)(exp⁡(ϵkBT)+1)−2C=\frac{d E}{d T}=N k_{B}\left(\frac{\epsilon}{k_{B} T}\right)^{2} \exp \left(\frac{\epsilon}{k_{B} T}\right)\left(\exp \left(\frac{\epsilon}{k_{B} T}\right)+1\right)^{-2}C=dTdE​=NkB​(kB​Tϵ​)2exp(kB​Tϵ​)(exp(kB​Tϵ​)+1)−2

vanishes at both low and high temperatures. The vanishing of CCC as exp⁡(−ϵ/kBT)\exp \left(-\epsilon / k_{B} T\right)exp(−ϵ/kB​T) at low temperatures is characteristic of all systems with an energy gap separating the ground state and lowest excited states. The vanishing of CCC at high temperatures is a saturation effect, common to systems with a maximum in the number of states as a function of energy. In between, the heat capacity exhibits a peak at a characteristic temperature of Tϵ∝ϵ/kBT_{\epsilon} \propto \epsilon / k_{B}Tϵ​∝ϵ/kB​.

Statistical mechanics provides much more than just macroscopic quantities such as energy and heat capacity. Eq.(IV.16) is a complete joint probability distribution with considerable information on the micro-states. For example, the unconditional probability for exciting a particular impurity is obtained from

p(n1)=∑{n2,⋯ ,nN}p({ni})=Ω(E−n1ϵ,N−1)Ω(E,N)p\left(n_{1}\right)=\sum_{\left\{n_{2}, \cdots, n_{N}\right\}} p\left(\left\{n_{i}\right\}\right)=\frac{\Omega\left(E-n_{1} \epsilon, N-1\right)}{\Omega(E, N)}p(n1​)={n2​,⋯,nN​}∑​p({ni​})=Ω(E,N)Ω(E−n1​ϵ,N−1)​

The second equality is obtained by noting that once the energy taken by the first impurity is specified, the remaining energy must be distributed among the other N−1N-1N−1 impurities. Using eq.(IV.17),

p(n1=0)=Ω(E,N−1)Ω(E,N)=(N−1)!N1!(N−N1−1)!⋅N1!(N−N1)!N!=1−N1Np\left(n_{1}=0\right)=\frac{\Omega(E, N-1)}{\Omega(E, N)}=\frac{(N-1) !}{N_{1} !\left(N-N_{1}-1\right) !} \cdot \frac{N_{1} !\left(N-N_{1}\right) !}{N !}=1-\frac{N_{1}}{N}p(n1​=0)=Ω(E,N)Ω(E,N−1)​=N1​!(N−N1​−1)!(N−1)!​⋅N!N1​!(N−N1​)!​=1−NN1​​

and p(n1=1)=1−p(n1=0)=N1/Np\left(n_{1}=1\right)=1-p\left(n_{1}=0\right)=N_{1} / Np(n1​=1)=1−p(n1​=0)=N1​/N. Using N1=E/ϵN_{1}=E / \epsilonN1​=E/ϵ, and eq.(IV.21), the occupation probabilities at a temperature TTT are

p(0)=11+exp⁡(−ϵkBT), and p(1)=exp⁡(−ϵkBT)1+exp⁡(−ϵkBT)p(0)=\frac{1}{1+\exp \left(-\frac{\epsilon}{k_{B} T}\right)}, \quad \text { and } \quad p(1)=\frac{\exp \left(-\frac{\epsilon}{k_{B} T}\right)}{1+\exp \left(-\frac{\epsilon}{k_{B} T}\right)}p(0)=1+exp(−kB​Tϵ​)1​, and p(1)=1+exp(−kB​Tϵ​)exp(−kB​Tϵ​)​

# Introduction to Tex Decks!

TexDeck.net is a collection of resources assembled to make LaTeX rich flashcards easier to write, remix, and organize.

The effect: Low cost active learning, allowing one's knowledge of science to scale sustainably.

A [[case study]] is in progress to seed the flashcard repository using a course in [nanoelectronics](https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-701-introduction-to-nanoelectronics-spring-2010/) from [OpenCourseWare](https://ocw.mit.edu/)

((ref:[[case study.1 motivation]]))

### How does the system work?

....

### Intellectual Property

All work is [CC-BY-SA 4.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/) unless otherwise specified at the top of a page. I cannot really enforce the attribution clause, but I do highly reccomend it. If you find these resources useful, consider sharing them with others.

Also, keep in mind that this is a work in progress and may contain errors. [Pull requests on these study resources](https://github.com/Stedag/ocwphy) are encouraged.

Despite accumulating a good deal of notes as part of my B.S. I will not include any of school notes among these resources to honor copyright agreements with my department. Nonetheless I forsee monotonic aggregation of resources organized around OCW classes or open-access textbooks.

For any concerns regarding IP, open an issue on github.
